section-block.rac_essential-question: What can we learn from using our senses?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Tim Hopgood
section-block.rac_book_summary: This story introduces children to some of the many ways we can use our five senses to learn about the world. Discover how Hoppy knows it is spring and why all the rabbits shout, “Hooray!”

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children you can count any objects. Count items in the classroom together, like tables or windows. Remind them that we say one number for each item.
Sing a song with children that has numbers, such as “Five Green and Speckled Frogs.” As you sing, have children hold up a number of fingers for the number you are on.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Hooray for Hoppy! by Tim Hopgood.
Lala loves books like this that teach us true information.
There’s a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does Hoppy know spring has sprung?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: Pause and ask children to count items in the images as you read.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Hoppy says “hooray” because he hears birds and he knows that birds come out during spring. (MB)
How many birds are there? Let’s all count together as I point.
Flowers open and smell nice in spring. How many flowers are there? Let’s count them together.
What do you think it means that “spring has sprung?” What else happens in spring?
Hoppy feels the ground is warm. Why is he so happy about it? (MB)
I don’t think Hoppy has seen his friends all winter! That must be why he is so excited that spring has sprung.
We use our five senses to understand the world around us.
Let’s talk about the guiding question: How does Hoppy know spring has sprung?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to respond to the guiding question.
Write and read aloud short sentences using the five senses to tell about a season.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does smelling flowers let Hoppy know it is spring?
In spring, the flowers start to bloom and sm___ (smell) nice.
In spring, the flowers start to bloom and smell nice.
How is spring different than winter?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Provide plenty of opportunity for physical involvement, such as pointing to ears to explain the sense of sound and pointing to eyes to indicate the sense of sight. This reinforces vocabulary without the added complexity of needing to understand definitions as well.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder:Talk About Your Feelings
section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss emotions with children. Explain that when you feel good, you might feel happy or excited. When you feel bad, you might feel sad or angry. Explaining how you feel helps other people to understand you better. Talking about your own feelings helps you learn to notice and say how other people are feeling.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread some pages in Hooray for Hoppy! by Tim Hopgood. We will talk about how Hoppy feels when spring is coming.
Clifford feels good. He is happy to read a book with all of you.

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: Remind children that when you count items there is one-to-one correspondence.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Hoppy really wants it to be spring. What emotions does Hoppy have when he sees that everything is still covered in snow and ice? (MB)
How does Hoppy use the sounds he hears to know that it is spring?
How does Hoppy feel when he hears the birds singing? How do you know? (MB)
Why does Hoppy keep saying “Hooray!”? (MB)
How many lambs is he watching? Let’s count them. We say one number for each lamb. Remember, the last number we say is the number of lambs in all.
Hoppy is happy that it is warm and sunny outside! How do you feel when you step outside and it is warm and sunny? (MB)
Why do you think Hoppy can’t wait to see his friends? How does Hoppy feel? (MB)
What senses do Hoppy’s friends use when Hoppy thumps his feet?
Hoppy leaps into the air. How do you think Hoppy feels? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Point out that Hoppy makes sounds to call his rabbit friends. Have children make up a special call to their friends using their feet. Have each child demonstrate their special call, and then repeat altogether. Count thumps when possible.
Transcribe children’s speech as they share their feelings about spring.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Learning to identify different emotions and corresponding behaviors is not only critical for fostering interpersonal relationships and empathy, but also crucial in helping children understand their own behaviors. Recognizing the link between emotions and behavior helps children regulate their own emotions and control their own behaviors. (Denham, Burton, 2003)

section-block.rac_body-text: Review ordinal terms and order with children. Arrange five different items in a sequence and point out which is first, second, third, fourth, and last. Rearrange and repeat.
Give children three movements to do, such as clapping, wiggling, and jumping. Model all three, then say what order to do them in. Ask which was first, second, and last.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Hooray for Hoppy! by Tim Hopgood.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use the Lala the Lizard puppet.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Lala loves reading books about animals.
As we read today, I want you to think about this question:

section.rac_body-text: Facilitate back-and-forth conversation with children to extend the language. Pause to discuss the order of events as you read.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read, we can think about the order Hoppy does things.
What does Hoppy do first? What sense does he use to sniff the air?
What does Hoppy do on the second morning? What sense does he use to know the grass is crunchy and the air is cold?
What changes on the next day? What does Hoppy’s sense of smell tell him?
Hoppy uses his ears and sense of sound and his nose and sense of smell to know it is spring. What does he do first? What does he do second?
What sense is Hoppy using to look at the lambs?
Hoppy is really sure it is spring. What is the last sense that Hoppy uses to know it is spring? What does he feel?
First, Hoppy doesn’t see any friends. What does he do second? What senses do the other rabbits use when Hoppy thumps his back feet as hard as he can?
How many senses do we use? What are they?
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today?
section.rac_body-text: Ask children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose several children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Hoppy uses his eyes to see.
Hoppy uses his ears to hear.
Hoppy uses his nose to smell.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about using senses.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Hoppy use his eyes for?
Hoppy uses his eyes to s__ (see).
Hoppy uses his eyes to see.
What senses do you use as we read the story together?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: At this age, children are starting to tell stories and understand time. Because they understand the idea of counting, they can recall parts of a story by listing the events in order: first, second, last. Encourage them to use the same words when they are telling a story.

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children the counting sequence is always the same, no matter what you are counting. Count out two batches of five items. Explain that the order is the same.
Play a version of I spy using eyes and/or ears. Say, I spy/here with my little eye/ear. Describe for children a nearby item or a sound and have children guess what it is.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch! It is an informational poster about our five senses!
Lala likes to read informational posters and learn about what the pictures show.
See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch! and Hooray for Hoppy! each focus on our five senses. Let’s look for any connections between the two as we read!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Hooray for Hoppy! book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
What can we learn from using our senses?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Five Senses
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask questions that provide opportunities to count.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How many senses are shown? Let’s count!
What body part do we use when using our sense of sight? Can you see three things that are red?
What can you use your nose to smell?
What sense are you using when you hear with your ears?
What sounds do you like to hear?
Your sense of taste helps you decide if you like the food you are eating. What body part do you use to taste foods?
What part of your body do you use to touch something? What is something you feel right now?

section.rac_body-text: Play a version of Simon Says with senses instead of motions. Say, Simon says this is for (seeing, hearing, tasting, smelling, or touching.) All children should touch their eyes, ears, mouth, or nose or wiggle their fingers to show which sense is being used.
Make sure to say each sense at least once.
Provide a writing prompt about using senses to learn about the world. Give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: In order to count a set of items, children need to know the number words in order and be able to match one number word to one item while counting. Children also need to keep track of which items have been counted. Children can use their fingers to keep track while counting, point to objects one at a time, and move objects as they’re counted.

section-block.rac_body-text: Point out how ordinal terms are used to help describe what happens in a book. Use Hooray for Hoppy! and identify what happens first, second, and so on.
Sing “If You’re Happy and You Know It” with children. Replace happy with Hoppy and emphasize body parts used for senses, such as “sniff with your nose,” “move your hands.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read Hooray for Hoppy! one more time.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Lala the Lizard Stick Puppet.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This book is a story that teaches real information about spring and our senses.
We have learned about different senses and what we do with them. When we read today, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What does Hoppy learn using his senses?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time. This time, we will all act like Hoppy and his friends.
What does Hoppy learn from seeing the snow outside? Pretend like you just found snow outside. Show how you feel about it. (MB)
How do you think Hoppy knows it is spring? What do you think Hoppy smells? Let’s all sniff with our noses.
How many flowers does Hoppy sniff? Pretend to sniff flowers with him. Why do you think the flowers tell Hoppy that it is spring?
How does Hoppy use his sense of sight to help him learn that it is spring? What does he see?
Why do you think Hoppy says “it tastes like spring has sprung”? Let’s pretend to be rabbits tasting grass.
What does Hoppy touch that tells him it is spring? Let’s all hop like our feet are on warm ground?
What numbers do you see on these pages? What are the five senses?
Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What does Hoppy learn using his senses?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Hoppy learns that the grass tastes fresh.
Hoppy learns it is warm out.
Hoppy learns that it is spring.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a story about how they use their five senses to learn about their world and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Hoppy’s sense of taste help him learn?
Hoppy learns that the grass tastes fr___ (fresh).
Hoppy learns that the grass tastes fresh.
What can we learn about the world around us with our senses?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Helping children understand and identify numerals when talking about amounts lays groundwork for future mathematic skills. The ability of young children to compare two numerals as a symbolic representation of numbers is associated with later success in math more than the ability to compare actual amounts.
